cip.render.raytrace.material.texture

Class Checkerboard

  • java.lang.Object
    • cip.render.ADynamicNamedObject
      • cip.render.raytrace.material.texture.ATexture
        • cip.render.raytrace.material.texture.ADualMaterialTexture
          • cip.render.raytrace.material.texture.Checkerboard
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    IDynXmlObject, INamedObject, IRtMaterial
    Direct Known Subclasses:
    SpheresTexture

    public class Checkerboard
extends ADualMaterialTexture
    Maps every unit square (in 2D) or cube (in 3D) into 4 unit squares (2D) or 8 unit cubes (3D) with alternating materials in the squares or cubes. For a 2D mapping (such as natural mappings) this gives a checkerboard pattern of material1 and material2. For a 3D mapping (such as a linear mapping in object space), this gives the effect of the object having been sculpted out of a 3D checkerboard of material1 and material2. Within each mapped square or cube, the textures coordinates are normalized to be in the 0,0,0 to 1,1,1 range.

    The checkerboard mapping is specified as: 

         <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="cip.raytrace.material.texture.Checkerboard"
                              name="checkerboardName">
         <material1>
             <MaterialByRef name="materialName"/>
             <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="materialClass">
                   .
                 material specific nodes and attributes
                   .
             </DynamicallyLoadedObject>
         </material1>
         <material2>
             <MaterialByRef name="materialName"/>
             <DynamicallyLoadedObject class="materialClass">
                   .
                 material specific nodes and attributes
                   .
    
             </DynamicallyLoadedObject>
         </material2>
     </DynamicallyLoadedObject>
    where:
    material1 The material in the ((i < .5) and (j < .5)) or ((i > .5) and (j > .5)) quadrants of a 2D mapping (texture Z = 0) of a unit square, and in the ((i < .5) and (j < .5) and (k < .5)) or ((i > .5) and (j > .5) and (k < .5)) or ((i < .5) and (j > .5) and (k > .5)) or ((i > .5) and (j < .5) and (k > .5)).
    material2 The material in the quadrants that aren't material1.
    MaterialByRef A material specfied by reference to the name of a previously loaded material. MaterialByRef is mutually exclusive with the DynamicallyLoadedObject specification of a material. If no material is specified the mapping will generate an exception during rendering.
    DynamicallyLoadedObject The specification fof a material for the sphere. MaterialByRef is mutually exclusive with the DynamicallyLoadedObject specification of a material. The dynamically loaded object must implement the IRtMaterial interface. If no material is specified the mapping will generate an exception during rendering.
    Since:
    1.0

      • getColor

        public void getColor(@NotNull
                     @NotNull RGBf rgb,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull RayIntersection intersection,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtLight[] lights,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtGeometry[] rtObjects,
                     @NotNull
                     @NotNull IRtBackground rtBkg,
                     int nMaxRecursions,
                     int nSample,
                     int nRandom)
        Description copied from interface: IRtMaterial
        Compute the colour of a surface as seen from a specific direction.
        Parameters:
        rgb - (modified) The computed colour at the surface.
        intersection - (readonly) The description of the surface - location, orientation, material, etc.
        lights - (readonly) The light in the scene that may affect the intersection.
        rtObjects - (readonly) The objects in the scene.
        rtBkg - (readonly) The background description.
        nMaxRecursions - The maximum reflections to be followed in computing this colour.
        nSample - The pixel sub-sample index. This is used in distributed ray-tracing to make sure the correct sample displacement is used for samples that are distributed.
        nRandom - The jitter array index..
